trans-unit.source: ms.ContentId: 4981828d-1a08-4d8c-a99d-874a926a153f title: PowerShell to Docker Comparison
trans-unit.target: ms.ContentId: 4981828d-1a08-4d8c-a99d-874a926a153f title: PowerShell to Docker Comparison

trans-unit.source: PowerShell to Docker comparison for managing Windows Server Containers
trans-unit.target: PowerShell to Docker comparison for managing Windows Server Containers

trans-unit.source: Updating contents on 27-Oct for testing.
trans-unit.target: Updating contents on 27-Oct for testing.

trans-unit.source: There are many ways to manage Windows Server Containers using both in-box Windows tools (PowerShell, in this preview) and Open Source management tools such as Docker.
trans-unit.target: There are many ways to manage Windows Server Containers using both in-box Windows tools (PowerShell, in this preview) and Open Source management tools such as Docker.

trans-unit.source: Guides outlining both individually available here:
trans-unit.target: Guides outlining both individually available here:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Manage Windows Server Containers with Docker</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Manage Windows Server Containers with Docker</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Manage Windows Server Containers with PowerShell</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Manage Windows Server Containers with PowerShell</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: This page is a more in depth reference comparing the Docker tools and PowerShell management tools.
trans-unit.target: This page is a more in depth reference comparing the Docker tools and PowerShell management tools.

trans-unit.source: PowerShell for containers versus Hyper-V VMs
trans-unit.target: PowerShell for containers versus Hyper-V VMs

trans-unit.source: You can create, run, and interact with Windows Server Containers using PowerShell cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: You can create, run, and interact with Windows Server Containers using PowerShell cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: Everything you need to get going is available in-box.
trans-unit.target: Everything you need to get going is available in-box.

trans-unit.source: If you’ve used Hyper-V PowerShell, the design of the cmdlets should be pretty familiar to you.
trans-unit.target: If you’ve used Hyper-V PowerShell, the design of the cmdlets should be pretty familiar to you.

trans-unit.source: A lot of the workflow is similar to how you’d manage a virtual machine using the Hyper-V module.
trans-unit.target: A lot of the workflow is similar to how you’d manage a virtual machine using the Hyper-V module.

trans-unit.source: Instead of New-VM, Get-VM, Start-VM, Stop-VM, you have New-Container, Get-Container, Start-Container, Stop-Container.
trans-unit.target: Instead of New-VM, Get-VM, Start-VM, Stop-VM, you have New-Container, Get-Container, Start-Container, Stop-Container.

trans-unit.source: There are quite a few container-specific cmdlets and parameters, but the general lifecycle and management of a Windows container looks roughly like that of a Hyper-V VM.
trans-unit.target: There are quite a few container-specific cmdlets and parameters, but the general lifecycle and management of a Windows container looks roughly like that of a Hyper-V VM.

trans-unit.source: How does PowerShell management compare to Docker?
trans-unit.target: How does PowerShell management compare to Docker?

trans-unit.source: The Containers PowerShell cmdlets expose an API that isn’t quite the same as Docker's; as a general rule, the cmdlets are more granular in operation.
trans-unit.target: The Containers PowerShell cmdlets expose an API that isn’t quite the same as Docker's; as a general rule, the cmdlets are more granular in operation.

trans-unit.source: Some Docker commands have pretty straightforward parallels in PowerShell:
trans-unit.target: Some Docker commands have pretty straightforward parallels in PowerShell:

trans-unit.source: Docker command
trans-unit.target: Docker command

trans-unit.source: PowerShell Cmdlet
trans-unit.target: PowerShell Cmdlet

trans-unit.source: docker ps -a
trans-unit.target: docker ps -a

trans-unit.source: Get-Container
trans-unit.target: Get-Container

trans-unit.source: docker images
trans-unit.target: docker images

trans-unit.source: Get-ContainerImage
trans-unit.target: Get-ContainerImage

trans-unit.source: docker rm
trans-unit.target: docker rm

trans-unit.source: Remove-Container
trans-unit.target: Remove-Container

trans-unit.source: docker rmi
trans-unit.target: docker rmi

trans-unit.source: Remove-ContainerImage
trans-unit.target: Remove-ContainerImage

trans-unit.source: docker create
trans-unit.target: docker create

trans-unit.source: New-Container
trans-unit.target: New-Container

trans-unit.source: docker commit
trans-unit.target: docker commit

trans-unit.source: New-ContainerImage -Container
trans-unit.target: New-ContainerImage -Container

trans-unit.source: docker load
trans-unit.target: docker load

trans-unit.source: Import-ContainerImage
trans-unit.target: Import-ContainerImage

trans-unit.source: docker save
trans-unit.target: docker save

trans-unit.source: Export-ContainerImage
trans-unit.target: Export-ContainerImage

trans-unit.source: docker start
trans-unit.target: docker start

trans-unit.source: Start-Container
trans-unit.target: Start-Container

trans-unit.source: docker stop
trans-unit.target: docker stop

trans-unit.source: Stop-Container
trans-unit.target: Stop-Container

trans-unit.source: The PowerShell cmdlets are not an exact perfect parity, and there are a fair number of commands that we’re not providing PowerShell replacements for* (notably docker build and docker cp).
trans-unit.target: The PowerShell cmdlets are not an exact perfect parity, and there are a fair number of commands that we’re not providing PowerShell replacements for* (notably docker build and docker cp).

trans-unit.source: But what might leap out at you is that there’s no single one-line replacement for docker run.
trans-unit.target: But what might leap out at you is that there’s no single one-line replacement for docker run.

trans-unit.source: \* Subject to change.
trans-unit.target: \* Subject to change.

trans-unit.source: But I need docker run! What’s going on?
trans-unit.target: But I need docker run! What’s going on?

trans-unit.source: We’re doing a couple things here to provide a slightly more familiar interaction model for users who know their way around PowerShell already.
trans-unit.target: We’re doing a couple things here to provide a slightly more familiar interaction model for users who know their way around PowerShell already.

trans-unit.source: Of course, if you’re used to the way docker operates, this will be a bit of a mental shift.
trans-unit.target: Of course, if you’re used to the way docker operates, this will be a bit of a mental shift.

trans-unit.source: The lifecycle of a container in the PowerShell model is slightly different.
trans-unit.target: The lifecycle of a container in the PowerShell model is slightly different.

trans-unit.source: In the Containers PowerShell module, we expose the more granular operations of New-Container (which creates a new container that’s stopped) and Start-Container.
trans-unit.target: In the Containers PowerShell module, we expose the more granular operations of New-Container (which creates a new container that’s stopped) and Start-Container.

trans-unit.source: In between creating and starting the container, you can also configure the container’s settings; for TP3, the only other configuration we’re planning to expose is the ability to set the network connection for the container.
trans-unit.target: In between creating and starting the container, you can also configure the container’s settings; for TP3, the only other configuration we’re planning to expose is the ability to set the network connection for the container.

trans-unit.source: using the (Add/Remove/Connect/Disconnect/Get/Set)-ContainerNetworkAdapter cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: using the (Add/Remove/Connect/Disconnect/Get/Set)-ContainerNetworkAdapter cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: You can’t currently pass a command to be run inside the container on start. However, you can still get an interactive PowerShell session to a running container using Enter-PSSession -ContainerId , and you can execute a command inside a running container using Invoke-Command -ContainerId -ScriptBlock { code to run inside the container } or Invoke-Command -ContainerId -FilePath . Both of these commands allow the optional -RunAsAdministrator flag for high privilige actions.
trans-unit.target: You can’t currently pass a command to be run inside the container on start. However, you can still get an interactive PowerShell session to a running container using Enter-PSSession -ContainerId , and you can execute a command inside a running container using Invoke-Command -ContainerId -ScriptBlock { code to run inside the container } or Invoke-Command -ContainerId -FilePath . Both of these commands allow the optional -RunAsAdministrator flag for high privilige actions.

trans-unit.source: Caveats and known issues
trans-unit.target: Caveats and known issues

trans-unit.source: Right now, the Containers cmdlets have no knowledge about any containers or images created through Docker, and Docker does not know anything about containers and images created through the PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Right now, the Containers cmdlets have no knowledge about any containers or images created through Docker, and Docker does not know anything about containers and images created through the PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: If you created it in Docker, manage it with Docker; if you created it through PowerShell, manage it through PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: If you created it in Docker, manage it with Docker; if you created it through PowerShell, manage it through PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: We have quite a bit of work we'd like to do to improve the end user experience -- better error messages, better progress reporting, invalid event strings, and so forth.
trans-unit.target: We have quite a bit of work we'd like to do to improve the end user experience -- better error messages, better progress reporting, invalid event strings, and so forth.

trans-unit.source: If you happen to run into a situation where you wish you were getting more or better info, please feel free to send suggestions to the forums.
trans-unit.target: If you happen to run into a situation where you wish you were getting more or better info, please feel free to send suggestions to the forums.

trans-unit.source: A quick runthrough
trans-unit.target: A quick runthrough

trans-unit.source: Here is a walk through of some common workflows.
trans-unit.target: Here is a walk through of some common workflows.

trans-unit.source: This assumes you've installed an OS container image named "ServerDatacenterCore" and created a virtual switch named "Virtual Switch" (using New-VMSwitch).
trans-unit.target: This assumes you've installed an OS container image named "ServerDatacenterCore" and created a virtual switch named "Virtual Switch" (using New-VMSwitch).

trans-unit.source: Build your own sample
trans-unit.target: Build your own sample

trans-unit.source: You can see all the Containers cmdlets using Get-Command -Module Containers.
trans-unit.target: You can see all the Containers cmdlets using Get-Command -Module Containers.

trans-unit.source: There are several other cmdlets that are not described here, which we'll leave to you to learn about on your own.
trans-unit.target: There are several other cmdlets that are not described here, which we'll leave to you to learn about on your own.

trans-unit.source: Note This won't return the Enter-PSSession and Invoke-Command cmdlets, which are part of core PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Note This won't return the Enter-PSSession and Invoke-Command cmdlets, which are part of core PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: You can also get help about any cmdlet using Get-Help [cmdlet name], or equivalently [cmdlet name] -?.
trans-unit.target: You can also get help about any cmdlet using Get-Help [cmdlet name], or equivalently [cmdlet name] -?.

trans-unit.source: Today, the help output is auto-generated and just tells you the syntax for commands; we will be adding further documentation as we get closer to finalizing the cmdlet design.
trans-unit.target: Today, the help output is auto-generated and just tells you the syntax for commands; we will be adding further documentation as we get closer to finalizing the cmdlet design.

trans-unit.source: A nicer way to discover the syntax is the PowerShell ISE, which you may not have looked at before if you haven't used PowerShell very much.
trans-unit.target: A nicer way to discover the syntax is the PowerShell ISE, which you may not have looked at before if you haven't used PowerShell very much.

trans-unit.source: If you're running on a SKU that permits it, try starting the ISE, opening the Commands pane, and choosing the "Containers" module, which will show you a graphical representation of the cmdlets and their parameter sets.
trans-unit.target: If you're running on a SKU that permits it, try starting the ISE, opening the Commands pane, and choosing the "Containers" module, which will show you a graphical representation of the cmdlets and their parameter sets.

trans-unit.source: PS: Just to prove it can be done, here's a PowerShell function that composes some of the cmdlets we've seen already into an ersatz docker run.
trans-unit.target: PS: Just to prove it can be done, here's a PowerShell function that composes some of the cmdlets we've seen already into an ersatz docker run.

trans-unit.source: (To be clear, this is a proof of concept, not under active development.)
trans-unit.target: (To be clear, this is a proof of concept, not under active development.)

trans-unit.source: Docker
trans-unit.target: Docker

trans-unit.source: Windows Server Containers can be managed with Docker commands.
trans-unit.target: Windows Server Containers can be managed with Docker commands.

trans-unit.source: While Windows containers should be comparable to their Linux counterparts and have the same management experience through Docker, there are some Docker commands that simply don't make sense with a Windows container.
trans-unit.target: While Windows containers should be comparable to their Linux counterparts and have the same management experience through Docker, there are some Docker commands that simply don't make sense with a Windows container.

trans-unit.source: Others simply haven't been tested (we're getting there).
trans-unit.target: Others simply haven't been tested (we're getting there).

trans-unit.source: In an effort to not duplicate the API documentation available in Docker, here is a link to their management APIs.
trans-unit.target: In an effort to not duplicate the API documentation available in Docker, here is a link to their management APIs.

trans-unit.source: Their walkthroughs are fantastic.
trans-unit.target: Their walkthroughs are fantastic.

trans-unit.source: We're tracking things that do and don't work in the Docker APIs in our Work in Progress document.
trans-unit.target: We're tracking things that do and don't work in the Docker APIs in our Work in Progress document.
